folder: Hamilton Avenue & Huntington Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Hamilton Avenue (right), east side, south from Huntington to Clinton Streets. On the left is Huntington Street extending to Clinton Street. This group of buildings forms a triangle bounded by the above mentioned streets and was torn down several years later when Hamilton Avenue was widened, to become Gowanus Parkway, Brooklyn's northerly extension of the Belt Parkway.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: June 25, 1931
View 2: July 24, 1940

view 2: Neg. No. A-1045

folder: Hamilton Avenue & Huntington Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Hamilton Avenue, north from Huntington Street, showing the demolition of buildings for the construction of Gowanus Parkway, the highway which will carry automobile traffic to and from the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.

October 23, 1940

P. L. Sperr

View 1, ✓
View 3: July 26, 1940

view 3: Neg. No. A-1022

folder: Hamilton Avenue & Huntington Street, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Hamilton Avenue, east side, south from Huntington Street, showing the demolition of buildings to make possible the widening of the avenue as the northerly extension of the Belt Parkway. View 2 is south from Mill Street, two blocks below Huntington Street. On the left is the south side of Garnet Street.

September 7, 1940
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

View 3 is south from Mill Street and shows construction work on the Parkway after all the buildings were razed.

folder: Huntington Street & Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
text:
Huntington Street, north side, east from Hamilton Avenue to Clinton Street.

July 24, 1940

P. L. Sperr
